feed.title: NewsTracker: tunisia
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Tunisia terrorist attack will cost TUI up to ?32m, says Thomson and First Choice owner
entry.summary:
Thomson and First Choice owner TUI has said the terrorist massacre in Tunisia will have an impact on earnings of up to 32 million.

Tunisia has in the past represented 3% of the company's annual tour operator programmes.

entry.title: TUI Group's earnings hit by Greece & Tunisia fears
entry.summary: TUI's joint chief executives Friedrich Joussen and Peter Long said: "This quarter was marked by the tragic events in Tunisia at the end of June.

entry.title: Tunisia overwhelmingly passes anti-terror law
entry.summary: The report said Tunisia's police suffered from corruption, brutality and poor organization.

entry.title: Tunisia passes anti-terror law despite personal freedom concerns
entry.summary: Outrage over the attacks, which crippled Tunisia's vital tourism industry, swept aside reservations over the anti-terror legislation.

entry.title: Following devastating attacks, Tunisia overwhelmingly passes anti-terror law
entry.summary: Alone of all those countries, Tunisia has emerged with a democracy, but has since been tested by a rise in attacks by Islamic radicals.

entry.title: Tunisian parliament passes anti-terror law despite fears of rights violations
entry.summary:
TUNIS, Tunisia - Tunisia's parliament has voted overwhelmingly to pass the country's new anti-terror law despite fears by rights groups that it could be abused.

The sole country to emerge from the 2011 uprisings with a democracy, Tunisia has been targeted by militant groups.

entry.title: Tunisia police kill militant and arrest 13 others
Tunisia police kill suspected militant and arrest 13 others
entry.summary: One suspected militant has been killed and 13 others arrested in a late-night operation that foiled a planned attack in Tunisia.

entry.title: EU agrees to help Tunisia fight terror, boost economy
EU agrees to help Tunisia fight terror, boost economy
entry.summary:
BRUSSELS (AP) " The European Union has agreed to help Tunisia combat violent Islamic extremism and boost its economy, including by raising quotas on how much olive oil it can sell in EU markets.

EU foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini said it was in Europeans' own interest to assist Tunisia and its democratically elected government.
